OPTION I - To be unconditionally accepted into the program, applicants must have a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale. In addition, all applicants must have successfully completed: A major in Mathematics with a minimum of 30 credit hours in mathematics coursework, 12 of which must be at the 300-level or above. The coursework should include courses in calculus, linear algebra, geometry, abstract algebra, statistics/probability, and the history of mathematics.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in Childhood Inclusive Education
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: Our Master of Science in Education in Childhood Inclusive Education is a 30-credit program that prepares you to meet the needs of a wide range of students in today's diverse classrooms. This program is for students who already hold an initial certification in childhood education (grades 1-6) and are looking for a master's degree that can lead to a professional certification in both childhood education and students with disabilities (grades 1-6). The program of study includes classes focusing on the unique needs of children with disabilities, literacy instruction, and research.

ProgramName: Master of Science in College Student Affairs & Development
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Fees: $5,655 per semester (NY State Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State)
Fees.1: $5,655 per semester (NY State Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State)
Description: The Master of Science degree in college student affairs and development provides an opportunity for students interested in working in higher education to receive a professional education. The program’s mission is to educate professionals who are committed to creating systems that are accessible and equitable for all students. We use theory-to-practice and cohort-based models to prepare professionals who will engage with college students and challenge systems to bring about positive change. The program meets the academic standards of the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and aligns with the ACPA/NASPA Professional Competency Areas for Student Affairs Practitioners. This program is offered in a hybrid format. All classes have a combination of in-person and online instruction.
Accredidation: The program meets the academic standards of the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and aligns with the ACPA/NASPA Professional Competency Areas for Student Affairs Practitioners.
CostPerCredit: $471 per credit (NY State Resident); $963 per credit (Out-of-State)
ScholarshipAmount: Awards of at least $1,000; full or partial tuition scholarships and assistantships with tuition waivers and stipends are also available.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Computing Sciences
Description: The Master of Science in Computing Sciences program is designed for individuals who have an undergraduate degree in computer science or a related discipline and wish to deepen their knowledge and skills in this area. Our computing science graduate program provides students with a solid foundation in computer science through in-depth study of theory, software design, development and application of computers in a variety of fields. Students will learn how to: Apply theory to real-world problems. Master new technology. Work in a team. Take on leadership roles.
ScholarshipType: Diversity Fellowship, Graduate Opportunity Program, Promising Scholar Awards, Graduate Assistantships

Description: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Creative Writing is an 18-credit post-baccalaureate program designed for students who are interested in creating a collection of original creative work while improving their creative writing skills and deepening their knowledge of the literary arts. The CAS in Creative Writing is ideal for students who wish to pursue a Master of Fine Arts in creative writing but may lack the creative writing coursework to be a strong candidate. It is also an excellent option for current teachers who want to strengthen their creative writing pedagogy. Classes are available in a variety of creative writing genres, including creative nonfiction, fiction, and poetry. Other course topics include studies in literary form and theory, as well as creative writing pedagogy.

ProgramName: Doctor of Education in Educational Leadership
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: SUNY Brockport’s Doctor of Education (EdD) in Educational Leadership program is designed for practicing and aspiring P-12 school and district leaders. This innovative cohort-based program uses a practitioner-scholar model to develop students’ capacity to improve P-12 schools and districts. The program focuses on instructional leadership for equity, curriculum and instruction, organizational management, community relations, and leadership for social justice. This program is a member of the Carnegie Project on the Education Doctorate (CPED).
ScholarshipAmount: Awards range from $250 - $1,000 per year, and some tuition scholarships are available.
ScholarshipType: Graduate Diversity Fellowship, Promoting Excellence in Graduate Studies Scholarship, Fannie L. Porter Scholarship

ProgramName: Master of Arts in English – Creative Writing
Fees.1: $5,655 per semester (NYS Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State Resident)
ScholarshipAmount: $3,500 - $7,000 stipend per year, plus tuition waiver

ProgramName: Master of Arts in English – Literature
Requirements: A completed online application. Official transcripts from all accredited colleges or universities attended. A bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution. A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. A 300- to 500-word statement of objectives. A 10-15 page, typed, double-spaced critical writing sample on a literary topic. Three letters of recommendation. The GRE requirement is currently suspended.
Description: The MA in Literature at SUNY Brockport will develop your knowledge of literary history, theory, and criticism, while also honing your skills in close reading and scholarly writing. You’ll be prepared for advanced work in a doctoral program or for a variety of rewarding careers.
ScholarshipAmount: Stipend of approximately $8,000 for the academic year and a full tuition waiver.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Environmental Science & Ecology
Description: The Master of Science in Environmental Science and Ecology is a research-based program that stresses an individualized, multidisciplinary approach to environmental problem solving. The program encourages students to combine aspects of environmental science, ecology, biology, chemistry, geology, physical science, and other related fields to create a program tailored to their specific interests and career goals. Students have the opportunity to collaborate with a faculty advisor and graduate committee of their choosing to create a unique curriculum and conduct thesis research on a topic of interest.
ScholarshipType: Graduate Diversity Fellowships, Graduate Assistantships, Program-specific scholarships

Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must have: A bachelor’s degree from a regionally accredited US institution (or the equivalent from a foreign institution) with an undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher (on a 4.0 scale). Submitted a completed application to the Graduate School. Submitted official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Submitted two letters of recommendation from professional or academic references who can attest to their potential for success in a graduate program. Submitted a statement of objectives. Submitted a résumé.
Description: The Master of Healthcare Administration (MHA) program at SUNY Brockport prepares students for management and leadership careers in a wide range of healthcare settings, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, clinics, and community-based health organizations. Students learn to critically examine and evaluate issues and trends in the healthcare system. The curriculum is designed to provide both the breadth and depth of knowledge needed to succeed as a healthcare administrator. Courses emphasize healthcare organization, finance, reimbursement, law and ethics, quality improvement, and human resources. The MHA is a practice-based, professional degree. Students will apply classroom theory to the real-world in a culminating administrative internship in a healthcare organization of interest.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in Higher Education Administration
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description:
The Master of Science in Education in Higher Education Administration at SUNY Brockport is designed for individuals who seek or hold professional positions in administration and student support services at colleges and universities.

Our curriculum is aligned with the student affair standards established by the Council for the Advancement of Standards in Higher Education (CAS) and the American College Personnel Association (ACPA)/National Association of Student Personnel Administrators (NASPA). Students are taught by full-time faculty and student affairs administrators with extensive experience in the field.

Students are required to complete a minimum of one internship (3 credit hours) in an approved higher education setting. Those with limited or no prior higher education experience must complete two internships. In addition, there are many opportunities for volunteering, research, and professional development.

Students may also elect to complete a thesis on a higher education topic of interest, under the guidance of a faculty member.
ScholarshipAmount: Specific fellowships offer a stipend of at least $15,000 and a full tuition scholarship.

Description: The Master of Arts in History at SUNY Brockport offers students advanced training in historical study. Students in the program develop sophisticated research, writing, and analytical skills and expand their historical knowledge through coursework and independent study. The program prepares students for a variety of careers in fields such as secondary and post-secondary education, public history, and government service, as well as for further study in doctoral programs. The History M.A. program requires 30 credits of graduate work, including 24 credits of coursework and 6 credits dedicated to researching and writing a master’s thesis.
ScholarshipAmount: $7,000 stipend plus full tuition waiver for up to 18 credits

ProgramName: Master of Science in Instructional Design
Department: School of Education, Health, and Human Services
Description: The MSEd in Instructional Design prepares students for a wide variety of exciting careers in all sectors (corporate, non-profit, K-12, and higher education). Instructional designers create a wide variety of learning solutions. Our program prepares instructional designers to work in the ever-changing and fast-paced world of learning and performance improvement by grounding them in the foundational theories and allowing them to create a wide variety of learning experiences, from mobile learning to virtual reality.
ScholarshipAmount: Awards from $500 up to $5,000 plus tuition waivers are available.

Requirements: To be considered for admission, applicants must meet the following requirements: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited US institution or the international equivalent. An undergraduate GPA of 3.0 or higher is preferred. We will review applicants with a GPA below a 3.0 for provisional admission. Official transcripts from all previously attended colleges and universities. A current resume. A statement of objectives explaining why you are pursuing this certificate. Names and email addresses of three references who can attest to your academic and/or professional capabilities. International applicants are required to have a minimum TOEFL score of 550 paper-based or 79-80 internet-based; IELTS score of 6.5; or Duolingo score of 115.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: This 12-credit, fully online Advanced Certificate in Instructional Design at SUNY Brockport prepares students to design, develop, implement, and evaluate effective and engaging learning experiences. The certificate can be completed as a stand-alone program or taken as part of a master’s degree in Education. This certificate provides educators, instructional designers, and training specialists with the cutting-edge skills and knowledge required to design effective and engaging learning for K-12, higher education, and corporate/non-profit settings. Students will learn the essentials of instructional design, multimedia design and development, and project management. The program is built around the core competencies of the profession, including theoretical and practical foundations, planning and analysis, design and development, implementation and management, and evaluation and assessment.

ProgramName: Master of Arts in Liberal Studies
Description: The Master of Arts in Liberal Studies program is a graduate liberal studies program that allows students to study across the disciplines in the humanities, arts, natural sciences, and social sciences. It is an interdisciplinary program designed to meet the special needs and interests of individual students. The program provides a broad, interdisciplinary course of study for students who want to continue their education at the graduate level for intellectual enrichment, career advancement, or preparation for doctoral work.
ScholarshipAmount: $10,000 to $15,000 stipend and a full tuition scholarship for the Diversity Fellowship

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in Literacy Education Program
Requirements: Completed online application and paid fee. Bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university. Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. Official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended. Two letters of recommendation. New York State initial or professional teaching certification. Statement of objectives. Résumé. For applicants with an undergraduate GPA between 2.5 and 2.99, an additional writing sample is required. Please discuss a contemporary issue in the field of education. The issue should be supported by at least three current, professional sources.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The Master of Science in Education in Literacy Education is for candidates who currently hold a teaching certificate and are seeking to further their knowledge in the field of literacy. Our graduates become literacy leaders in their schools and districts, literacy coaches, and classroom teachers with specialized knowledge in literacy. We offer three different tracks to meet the needs of our diverse graduate students: B-6, 5-12, and B-12. Each program is 30-credits and is offered fully online.
Accredidation: The literacy education graduate programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
ScholarshipAmount: The Graduate Diversity Fellowship provides a full tuition scholarship and a $10,000 stipend.

Requirements:
Students applying for the Advanced Certificate in Local Government Management must have earned a bachelor’s degree from an accredited institution.

Application requires:
- Online application
- Official transcripts from all higher education institutions attended
- Two letters of recommendation
- A statement of objectives that addresses the applicant’s interest in the program and career goals
- Résumé
Description:
The Advanced Certificate in Local Government Management provides current and aspiring local government managers with the knowledge and skills necessary for a successful career as a public manager. Students will learn the fundamental skills of municipal management from expert faculty and practitioners in the field.

The Advanced Certificate program is ideal for part-time students who are currently employed by a local government and wish to take the next step in their careers. It can be completed in as little as 12 months. All courses are available in-person or online, providing maximum flexibility for working professionals. Full-time students can supplement their MPA or other graduate degrees with an Advanced Certificate, which allows students to develop specialized knowledge and skills that complement a graduate degree.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to full-tuition scholarship and a stipend of $7,500-$10,000 for specific fellowships.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Mental Health Counseling
Requirements:
A bachelor’s degree from an accredited college or university
A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0
Completion of at least 18 credits in the behavioral sciences (e.g., psychology, sociology, anthropology, human development, etc.) with a GPA of 3.0 or higher.
Completion of an undergraduate statistics course with a grade of C or higher.
Three letters of recommendation. It is strongly recommended that letters are from faculty who know your academic work.
A personal statement of 2-3 pages, double-spaced, that addresses your reasons for choosing mental health counseling as a profession.
A current resume.
An interview with program faculty (by invitation).
The GRE is not required.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The 60-credit hour Master of Science in Clinical Mental Health Counseling program is designed for students who want to become licensed mental health counselors (LMHC). The curriculum gives students all the educational requirements they need to become an LMHC in New York State. The curriculum has a strong focus on practice. All students take three semesters of clinical courses: practicum and a two-semester internship. SUNY Brockport has its own community mental health counseling training clinic that serves as one of our main training sites for our practicum and internship students.
Accredidation: The Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP), a specialized accrediting body recognized by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA), has granted accreditation to the Clinical Mental Health Counseling (MS) program at SUNY Brockport.

ProgramName: Certificate of Advanced Study in Mental Health Counseling Bridge
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Fees.1: $5,652 (NYS Resident) or $11,556 (Out-of-State) for the total program
Description: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Mental Health Counseling Bridge Program provides the opportunity for individuals who currently have a master’s degree in a related field (e.g., school counseling, rehabilitation counseling, social work, psychology) to complete the coursework required to be eligible for licensure as a mental health counselor in New York State. The Bridge Program requires a minimum of 24 credits. The specific number of credits required for each student is determined by a transcript review and in consultation with a faculty advisor.
ScholarshipType: Diversity fellowships, Merit-based scholarships, Graduate assistantships

Requirements:
An official transcript from the institution that awarded your bachelor’s degree.
Three letters of recommendation.
A personal statement describing why you are interested in nonprofit management.
A current resume.
A writing sample.
Fees.1: NYS Resident: $7,065; Out-of-State: $14,445 (for the entire 15-credit program)
Description: The Advanced Certificate in Nonprofit Management is a 15-credit, stand-alone certificate program that provides students with specific knowledge about the nonprofit sector. It also serves as a specialization for students in the Master of Public Administration (MPA) Program. The certificate program is appropriate for individuals currently employed in the nonprofit sector who are seeking additional professional development, for individuals who desire to become employed in the nonprofit sector, and for individuals whose employment requires them to interact with the nonprofit sector (e.g., government employees, board members).

ProgramName: Master of Science in Nursing - Adult Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner
Fees.1: $5,655 per semester (NYS Resident); $11,550 per semester (Out-of-State Resident)
Concentration: Adult Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner
Description: The Adult-Gerontology Primary Care Nurse Practitioner program prepares graduates to provide primary care to the entire spectrum of adults, including young adults, adults, and older adults. The primary care NP role includes providing comprehensive and continuous care to patients; this care is characterized by a long-term relationship between the patient and the NP. Primary care includes risk-reduction, health promotion, disease prevention, and the management of acute and chronic illnesses. The program emphasizes the development of expertise in health promotion, clinical assessment, and disease management and is guided by a commitment to the care of vulnerable and diverse populations. Our graduates work in a variety of settings, including primary care offices, long-term care facilities, specialty clinics, and correctional facilities.
Accredidation: The master’s degree program in nursing at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.

Fees: $471 per credit hour (NYS Resident); $963 per credit hour (Out-of-State Resident)
Fees.1: $471 per credit hour (NYS Resident); $963 per credit hour (Out-of-State Resident)
Description: Our Doctor of Nursing Practice (DNP) Program is a practice-focused doctoral program that prepares graduates to practice at the most advanced level of nursing. The program is designed for nurses who have earned a master's degree in nursing in an advanced practice specialty (e.g., nurse practitioner, clinical nurse specialist, nurse anesthetist, or nurse midwife), or in a specialty area of nursing leadership such as administration or informatics. Upon completion of the program, graduates will be able to: Provide leadership for evidence-based practice in a variety of settings. Apply clinical scholarship and analytical methods to improve patient outcomes. Serve as a catalyst for change to meet the health needs of a diverse society in a variety of settings. Advocate for health care policy to improve patient safety and quality of care.
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and Doctor of Nursing Practice program at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.
CostPerCredit: $471 per credit hour (NYS Resident); $963 per credit hour (Out-of-State Resident)

ProgramName: Certificate of Advanced Study in Nursing - Family Nurse Practitioner
Description: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) Family Nurse Practitioner (FNP) post-master’s program is a 33-credit program for registered nurses who hold a master’s degree in nursing and who wish to become an FNP. The program prepares students to provide primary care to individuals and families across the lifespan. The curriculum focuses on health promotion, disease prevention, and the diagnosis and management of common acute and chronic health problems. Upon completion of the program, students will be eligible to take the FNP certification exam.
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and post-graduate APRN certificate program at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to full tuition scholarship and a $10,000 stipend

ProgramName: Master of Science in Nursing - Family Nurse Practitioner
Description: The Master of Science, Family Nurse Practitioner program prepares graduates to provide primary care to individuals and families. The program has a strong emphasis on health promotion and disease prevention. The program is designed to be completed through part-time study to allow students to continue to work as they advance their education. All courses have an online component. Some courses are completely online and some are offered in a hybrid format, with a combination of online and in-person classes. Through our rigorous curriculum and practical training, you will learn to: diagnose and treat acute and chronic health problems, promote health and prevent disease, order and interpret diagnostic tests, prescribe medications and other therapies
Accredidation: The baccalaureate degree program in nursing, master's degree program in nursing, and post-graduate APRN certificate program at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Commission on Collegiate Nursing Education, 655 K Street NW, Suite 750, Washington, DC 20001, (202) 887-6791.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Nursing Education
Master of Science in Education in Physical Education - Adapted
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in Physical Education - Athletic Administration
Description: The Master of Science in Education in Physical Education is designed for individuals who are interested in advanced study within the field. Students can pursue one of three distinct tracks in our program: athletic administration, adapted physical education, or pedagogy. This track provides students the opportunity to combine their knowledge of physical education with the necessary business skills to become a successful athletic director at the interscholastic or intercollegiate level. The curriculum will prepare students to handle all aspects of an athletic program, including finance, legal issues, and marketing. A culminating experience of either a thesis, synthesis, or internship is required.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in Physical Education - Teacher Education Pedagogy
Requirements: In addition to the general requirements for all graduate applicants, you will also need to submit the following: A bachelor’s degree from an accredited US institution (or its equivalent from a foreign institution). A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0. Initial certification in Physical Education. Documentation of completion of the New York State Dignity For All Students Act (DASA) Training. Three letters of recommendation. A written statement of objectives. Official college transcripts from all institutions attended.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The Master of Science in Education (MSEd.) in Physical Education is intended for individuals who have completed an undergraduate physical education degree and hold initial New York State (NYS) certification in physical education. This program of study allows candidates to develop the pedagogical content knowledge necessary to meet the challenges of teaching physical education in the 21st century. The program has been nationally recognized by the Society for Health and Physical Educators (SHAPE America) and leads to professional certification in New York State.
Accredidation: The program has been nationally recognized by the Society for Health and Physical Educators (SHAPE America).

Requirements: To apply for the Master of Arts in Psychology program, you will need: an online graduate application, official transcripts from all colleges and universities attended, three letters of recommendation, a statement of purpose describing your academic and professional background, your career goals, and how the MA program in psychology will help you achieve these goals (approximately 500 words), a resume, and a writing sample that demonstrates your ability to write in a scientific style (e.g., a literature review or a research report). Admission requirements include a baccalaureate degree from an accredited institution, a minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale, and 18 credits in psychology, including statistics and research methods. Applicants are not required to submit GRE scores.
Description: Our Master of Arts in Psychology program offers a strong foundation in psychological science. Our students gain the skills necessary to conduct psychological research as well as to apply psychological principles to a variety of settings. We pride ourselves on the collaborative relationships our faculty form with our students. Students have numerous opportunities to collaborate with faculty on research through independent studies and research assistantships. Many students co-author conference presentations and journal articles with faculty. The MA program is a good fit for students who plan to pursue a doctoral degree or who want to work in a research setting. All full-time students are guaranteed a graduate assistantship that includes a stipend and tuition waiver. Our students have had a great deal of success after graduation. Over the past 10 years, over 80% of our graduates who applied to doctoral programs were accepted. Others have gone on to work in a variety of research and human service settings.
ScholarshipAmount: $500 to $1,500; Full tuition waivers also available

Requirements:
In addition to the general requirements for all graduate applicants, applicants to the MPA program must submit:

- A current résumé
- Two letters of recommendation from individuals such as a faculty member or a work supervisor who can speak to the applicant’s potential for graduate study and a career in public or nonprofit service.
- A 500-750 word essay that describes the applicant’s career goals and why an MPA will help achieve them.

Students are expected to have completed with a grade of “C” or better an undergraduate course in American government and a course in statistics.

Conditional admission may be granted to students who have not met these requirements.

Standardized test scores (e.g. GRE) are optional for all applicants.
Concentration: Health Care Management, Public Safety, Nonprofit Management
Description: SUNY Brockport’s Master of Public Administration (MPA) program is dedicated to enriching public and nonprofit life by preparing recent college graduates and mid-career professionals to be competent public managers and thoughtful public servants. Our graduates serve as leaders and managers in local, state, and federal government, as well as nonprofit organizations. Our curriculum is designed with the working professional in mind. The MPA degree is offered in two formats: a traditional on-campus format and a fully online format.
Accredidation: The MPA Program at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Network of Schools of Public Policy, Affairs, and Administration (NASPAA) Commission on Peer Review and Accreditation and is listed on the Annual Roster of Accredited Programs in conformity with NASPAA standards.

Requirements: Applicants to the Advanced Certificate in Public Health must meet the following requirements: Completed online graduate application with the application fee; Bachelor's degree from an accredited institution; Official transcripts from all colleges/universities attended; A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0; Two letters of recommendation; Statement of objectives; Current résumé.
Description:
The Advanced Certificate in Public Health is intended to provide graduate-level education in public health for individuals who may be working in or plan to work in public health settings. This program is available 100% online.
Upon completion of the program, students will be able to:
1. Explain public health history, philosophy, and values.
2. Identify the core functions of public health and the 10 Essential Services.
3. Explain the role of quantitative and qualitative methods and sciences in describing and assessing a population’s health.
4. List the major causes and trends of morbidity and mortality in the US or other community.
5. Discuss the science of primary, secondary and tertiary prevention in population health, including health promotion, screening, etc.
6. Explain the critical importance of evidence in advancing public health knowledge.
7. Explain effects of environmental factors on a population’s health.
8. Explain the social, political and economic determinants of health and how they contribute to population health and health inequities.
9. Explain how globalization affects global burdens of disease.
10. Explain an ecological perspective on the connections among human health, animal health and ecosystem health (e.g., One Health).
ScholarshipAmount: Awards of $1,000 up to a full tuition scholarship are available.

Requirements: Baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university with a GPA of 3.0 or higher. Official transcripts from all undergraduate and graduate institutions attended. A current resume. Three letters of recommendation from professional and/or academic references. A 500- to 750-word statement of purpose. The statement of purpose should describe the applicant’s interest in the field of public health, why they are interested in SUNY Brockport’s MPH Program, and their career goals. No GRE requirement. A non-refundable $75 application fee.
Description: Our Master of Public Health (MPH) degree will prepare you to be a public health leader. You will learn to address pressing public health issues at the local, state, national, and global levels. This program provides a strong foundation in the core areas of public health, including epidemiology, biostatistics, environmental health, health policy and management, and social and behavioral sciences. You will gain hands-on experience through a required internship, where you will apply your knowledge and skills in a real-world setting. Graduates of our program are well-equipped for careers in a variety of settings, including government agencies, non-profit organizations, and private industry.
Accredidation: The Master of Public Health program at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council on Education for Public Health (CEPH).

ProgramName: Certificate of Advanced Study in School Building/District Leader
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Educational Administration is offered in a fully online format and is designed for certified teachers and pupil personnel staff who have a master's degree and at least three years of professional experience. The CAS prepares graduates for New York State certification as a School Building Leader (SBL) and School District Leader (SDL). As a student in the Educational Administration program, you will learn to: lead and manage a school building and a school district; understand the link between theory, research, and the practice of educational leadership; develop skills to create and sustain a school culture and instructional program conducive to student learning and staff professional growth; collaborate with families and community members, responding to diverse community interests and needs and mobilizing community resources; and to act with integrity, fairness, and in an ethical manner.
Accredidation: The Educational Administration program at SUNY Brockport is nationally recognized by the National Council for Accreditation of Teacher Education (NCATE).
CostPerCredit: $471/credit for NYS residents; $963/credit for out-of-state residents

ProgramName: Certificate of Advanced Study in School Counseling
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in School Counseling is a 60-credit program for students who have a master’s degree in a related field and wish to become school counselors. The curriculum meets the academic requirements for provisional/permanent certification as a school counselor in New York State. The curriculum focuses on counseling, human development, and professional practice as it applies to school counseling. The program combines academic study with supervised practical experience in school counseling.
Accredidation: The Counselor Education programs at SUNY Brockport are accredited by the Council for Accreditation of Counseling and Related Educational Programs (CACREP).

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in School Counseling
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Master of Science in Education in School Counseling is a 60 credit hour program designed to prepare students for careers as school counselors in P-12 school settings. This program provides students with core knowledge and skills in the areas of human growth and development, social and cultural foundations, helping relationships, group work, career and lifestyle development, appraisal, research and program evaluation, and professional orientation. This program also provides students with the specialized knowledge and skills to become effective school counselors.
Accredidation: SUNY Brockport’s MSEd in School Counseling is a CACREP accredited program.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in School District Business Leader
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: Our Master of Science in Education in School District Business Leader prepares you to meet the NYS certification requirements for the School District Business Leader (SDBL). The SDBL is the chief financial officer of a school district. As SDBL, you are responsible for a variety of tasks including accounting, finance, and budgeting. This program is available 100% online. Our program is taught by experienced faculty, who have extensive experience in the field. Our program is designed to meet the rigorous demands and ever-changing environment in our school systems. You will learn about: Financial aspects of a school system including accounting, budgeting, state aid, purchasing, and capital projects; Management of all support services including food service, transportation, facilities, and technology; Personnel management, including contract negotiations and contract administration; State and Federal laws and regulations impacting school districts.
ScholarshipAmount: Varies by award, with some offering up to full tuition or stipends like $10,000 annually.

ProgramName: Certificate of Advanced Study in School District Business Leader
Requirements:
To be considered for admission, applicants to the Certificate of Advanced Study in School District Business Leader program must have the following:
- A completed online application
- A non-refundable application fee of $50
- Official transcripts from all accredited institutions of higher education attended, with one showing a master’s degree was conferred with a minimum GPA of 3.0 on a 4.0 scale
- Three letters of recommendation from professional and/or academic sources. Letters must be on official letterhead
- A statement of objectives that explains how this program relates to your professional goals (1-3 pages)
- A current resume detailing all professional experiences
- An interview with the SDBL Program Coordinator
- A copy of your initial or professional New York State teacher or pupil personnel services certification
- A minimum of three years of full-time teaching or pupil personnel services experience in N-12 schools
Description: The School District Business Leader (SDBL) Post-Master's Certificate program is a 21-credit program offered in a fully online format designed for students who already possess a master's degree and want to acquire New York State certification as a School District Business Leader. SDBL certification allows an individual to serve as the chief business official in a school district. The program develops the leadership and management skills necessary to effectively lead the business operations of a school district. The curriculum is composed of courses in school finance, school law, human resources and collective bargaining, principles of public school district leadership, and information management, followed by a one-year internship experience.
Accredidation: The SDBL program is registered by the New York State Education Department (NYSED) and is a CAEP accredited program.

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in School Health Education
Requirements:
Completed online graduate application.
Official transcript(s) from all accredited colleges and universities attended, with a minimum cumulative GPA of 3.0.
Professional resume.
Three letters of recommendation.
Statement of Objectives: a one-to-two-page typed statement addressing the question, 'Why do I want to become a health educator?'
Initial Teacher Certification in another subject area is required.
Interview with graduate program coordinator.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: Our Master of Science in Education in School Health Education prepares students for advanced-level careers in school health education. The program leads to professional certification for teaching health in New York State public schools. This program provides students who possess an initial teaching certificate in health with the graduate coursework necessary to earn professional teaching certification in New York State. Candidates who do not possess initial certification in health education may earn it by combining this program with the health education certification program.

Requirements:
A baccalaureate degree from an accredited college or university.
A minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 (on a 4.0 scale).
A liberal arts foundation with a minimum of 12 credits in the social sciences, 6 credits in the humanities and 3 credits in the biological sciences with a grade of 'C' or better.
Relevant human services experience (volunteer or paid) is strongly recommended for all applicants, and may be required of applicants with GPAs below a 3.25.
Students applying for advanced standing must have a BSW from a CSWE-accredited program earned within the last six years and a minimum 3.25 GPA in their social work major.
Concentration: Practice with children and families, Practice with older adults and their families
Description: The Master of Social Work (MSW) program at SUNY Brockport is designed for students who are committed to social justice and to serving oppressed and disadvantaged populations. It prepares students for advanced social work practice. We are the largest MSW program in the Rochester area. Our MSW program boasts a diverse student body, an outstanding faculty, a variety of exciting field placement opportunities, a student-centered approach to learning, and a rigorous curriculum designed to help students acquire the skills necessary for effective social work practice.
Accredidation: The Master of Social Work program at SUNY Brockport is accredited by the Council on Social Work Education (CSWE).

Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Fees.1: $5,655 per semester for NYS residents; $11,550 per semester for out-of-state residents. (Full-time, 9+ credits). Annual cost for NYS resident is $11,310.
Description: The Teacher Leader Program at SUNY Brockport is designed for practicing teachers who want to expand their professional impact beyond the classroom without leaving the classroom. The curriculum is intended to complement their existing teaching practices, not replace them. In fact, many of the projects in the program can be implemented in the candidate’s own classroom and school.
Accredidation: The Teacher Leader program is a registered program through the New York State Education Department.
CostPerCredit: $471 for NYS residents, $963 for out-of-state residents

ProgramName: Master of Science in Education in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: Teach English to speakers of other languages, and open yourself up to a world of opportunity. The Master of Science in Education in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages (TESOL) is for students who have a passion for other cultures and want to help non-native English speakers learn the English language. This 30-36 credit program will lead to an initial and/or professional certification in TESOL for pre-K-12 students. We also offer a non-certification track for those who wish to teach English to adult learners or in other settings that do not require NYS certification.
Accredidation: All teacher preparation programs are accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).
ScholarshipAmount: The Diversity Fellowship provides an annual stipend of $10,000 and a full tuition scholarship.

ProgramName: Advanced Certificate in Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description:
The Advanced Certificate in TESOL is intended for graduate students who already hold a master’s degree but wish to complete the requirements for New York State certification in English to Speakers of Other Languages (ESOL).

The program is 100% online, and can be completed by a full-time student in as few as three semesters. The Advanced Certificate program in TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of other Languages) is approved by the New York State Education Department for teacher certification, and completion of the program leads to a recommendation for certification for those who meet all requirements.

The department is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP). The Department of Education and Human Development has an excellent faculty who are well known in their fields and are highly respected for their scholarship, teaching, and service.

Students who complete the Advanced Certificate program in TESOL will be prepared to assist school districts in applying for ESOL teacher certification from the New York State Education Department.
Accredidation: The Advanced Certificate program in TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of other Languages) is approved by the New York State Education Department for teacher certification...The department is accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

Description:
The Advanced Certificate in Women & Gender Studies (WMS) is a 12-credit program that addresses historical and contemporary issues of women, gender, and sexuality from an interdisciplinary perspective. All students take WMS 601 Feminist Principles and WMS 602 Global Feminisms. You can complete the remainder of the program by taking nine credits of designated courses that deal with women, gender, and sexuality in different fields. Some of the many options include courses in Anthropology, Communication, Counselor Education, English, History, Public Administration, and Sociology. This certificate helps graduate students to broaden their knowledge in the exciting field of women and gender studies, and enhance their career opportunities.

The Advanced Certificate in Women & Gender Studies helps students to think critically about the ways that gender and sexuality shape our experiences. This certificate is valuable to students in a number of master’s programs, including history, English, public administration, and mental health counseling. It is also a good choice for people who work in human services, non-profit organizations, and education, who want to enhance their professional credentials.

Requirements: To apply, students must submit an online application (either the SUNY Application or the Common Application) and an official high school transcript. A letter of recommendation is optional but recommended. Test scores (SAT/ACT) are optional.
Description: Students completing the Accounting major are prepared for careers in public accounting (CPA firms), private accounting (business and not-for-profit organizations), and governmental accounting (local, state, and federal agencies). The program provides students with an understanding of financial accounting, managerial accounting, auditing, taxation, and accounting information systems. The curriculum, along with certain elective courses in other departments, also helps students meet the 150-hour education requirement for CPA licensure in New York State and other jurisdictions. Students typically pursue master's degrees to satisfy the 150-hour requirement. Students may also pursue Brockport's 4+1 BS/MS in Accounting program.

Requirements: Students who wish to minor in accounting must contact the department chair and file a 'Declaration of Minor' form in the Office of Academic Advisement. All students who wish to minor in accounting must complete the following courses with a minimum grade of C. Required Courses (6 credits): ACC 281 Principles of Financial Accounting; ACC 282 Principles of Managerial Accounting. Upper-Division Accounting Electives (12 credits).
Description: The Accounting minor provides non-business majors with foundational knowledge of financial and managerial accounting concepts. It helps students develop skills in analyzing, interpreting, and communicating financial information, which can be valuable in various professional fields. The minor may also serve as a stepping stone for students interested in pursuing an MBA or other graduate business programs.

Requirements: Prospective first-year students can apply using either the SUNY Application or the Common Application. Required application materials include the application and an official high school transcript. Other materials, such as letters of recommendation and a personal essay, are optional but strongly encouraged. SUNY Brockport is test-optional and does not require SAT or ACT scores for admission.
Description: The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Actuarial and Data Science at SUNY Brockport prepares students for careers in actuarial science and data science. The program includes a solid foundation in mathematics, statistics, computer science, and economics, along with practical skills in data analysis, modeling, and communication. Students will develop problem-solving skills, critical thinking, and ethical decision-making, while preparing to pass professional exams for actuarial science careers or pursue graduate studies in actuarial science, data science, or related fields.

The Certificate of Advanced Study (CAS) in Adapted Physical Education (APE) is designed to give students with a bachelor’s degree in Physical Education and/or Teaching Certification in Physical Education, the academic course work and field experiences to meet the New York State (NYS) requirements for teacher certification as an Adapted Physical Education teacher.

This 24-credit graduate certificate program may be completed in one year of full-time study or in two years of part-time study. Upon completion of the CAS in APE, candidates are eligible for initial/professional certification in APE through the NYS Education Department.

The CAS in APE at Brockport is offered as a stand-alone graduate certificate and as a concentration within the MS in Education (Physical Education or Health Education). Students interested in the MS in Education (Physical Education or Health Education) with a concentration in Adapted Physical Education will apply to the MS program and complete the 24-credits of APE coursework in addition to their core MS program requirements. Students in the CAS in APE are not required to complete a thesis or comprehensive exam.

Program Goals:
* To prepare future adapted physical education teachers with the knowledge and skills necessary to provide appropriate services to individuals with disabilities in physical education.
* To provide opportunities for candidates to demonstrate proficiency in the national adapted physical education standards.
* To provide opportunities for candidates to demonstrate proficiency in the NYS teaching standards for adapted physical education.
* To prepare candidates to meet the requirements for NYS teacher certification in adapted physical education.
* To provide candidates with opportunities to engage in applied research and scholarly activities.

Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: Brockport’s Addictions & Behavioral Health Major is a unique program dedicated to training the next generation of professionals to address the complex issues of addiction and mental health. This interdisciplinary degree prepares students to work in a variety of settings, including community agencies, hospitals, schools, and government organizations. You’ll learn to identify, prevent, and treat addiction and behavioral health issues through evidence-based practices, ethical considerations, and culturally sensitive approaches. Our curriculum emphasizes hands-on experience through internships and community engagement, ensuring graduates are well-prepared for immediate employment or further graduate studies in counseling, social work, public health, or related fields. Join us in making a difference in the lives of individuals, families, and communities affected by addiction and behavioral health challenges.

Requirements: This minor consists of 18 credits, 9 of which must be taken at SUNY Brockport. A grade of “C” or better must be earned in all minor courses.
Description: The Addictions and Behavioral Health Minor (non-clinical) at SUNY Brockport is designed for students interested in a variety of professions where knowledge about mental health and addiction is helpful but does not require direct clinical counseling. This minor is suitable for students pursuing careers in fields such as social work, public health, law enforcement, education, and human services, among others. Students will gain a strong foundation in understanding substance use disorders, behavioral addictions, mental health conditions, and co-occurring disorders. The curriculum covers topics such as assessment, prevention, treatment modalities, ethical considerations, and cultural competence, all from a non-clinical perspective. The minor prepares students to support individuals and communities affected by addiction and behavioral health challenges in roles that do not involve direct therapeutic intervention. This minor is not intended for students seeking to become licensed addiction counselors (CASAC).

Department: School of Arts and Sciences, School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: Our Adolescence Education: Biology (BS) program is designed for students who want to teach biology in grades 7-12. You'll gain a comprehensive understanding of biological concepts, including molecular biology, ecology, genetics, and evolution, while also developing the pedagogical skills necessary to effectively teach these subjects to adolescents. Our curriculum integrates theory with practical experience, providing opportunities for field experiences, lab work, and student teaching placements in local schools. Graduates of this program are prepared for New York State certification in Biology Grades 7-12.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Biology with Students with Disabilities Certification (BS)
Requirements: Freshman applicants must submit a completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application), an official high school transcript, a letter of recommendation, and a personal essay/statement. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, meaning students have the choice to submit SAT or ACT scores.
Department: School of Education, Health & Human Services
Description: This program of study leads to initial/professional New York State certification in Adolescence Education: Biology (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12) Generalist. It is designed for students who are interested in teaching biology to adolescents, including those with disabilities, in public and private schools. The curriculum focuses on both the subject matter of biology and the pedagogical skills required to teach effectively across a range of student needs and abilities. It is a dual certification program.
Accredidation: Accredited by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP)

Requirements: To apply to SUNY Brockport as a first-year student, you will need: a completed application (SUNY Application or Common Application), an official high school transcript, and an essay or personal statement. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, so you can choose whether or not to submit SAT or ACT scores. One letter of recommendation from a teacher or school counselor is optional but highly encouraged.
Description: The undergraduate Adolescence Education: Chemistry (BS) degree provides content in Chemistry and professional education leading to New York State initial certification in Adolescence Education: Chemistry (grades 7-12). It is designed for students seeking to become secondary school teachers of chemistry. Graduates are prepared to use a variety of instructional strategies, technologies, and assessments to support diverse student learners in the chemistry classroom. This program also meets the academic requirements for a BS in Chemistry.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Chemistry with Students with Disabilities Certification (BS)
Requirements: Prospective students must submit a completed SUNY Application or Common Application, an official high school transcript, and an essay/personal statement. A letter of recommendation is optional but encouraged. Standardized test scores (SAT/ACT) are optional.
Department: School of Arts & Sciences and School of Education, Health & Human Services
Concentration: Chemistry with Students with Disabilities Certification
Description: This program prepares students to teach chemistry to adolescents (grades 7-12) and to instruct students with disabilities within a general education setting. Upon successful completion of the program, students are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Adolescence Education: Chemistry and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).

The Adolescence Education: Earth Science (BS) program prepares students to become highly effective middle school and high school Earth science teachers. This program is offered in collaboration with the Department of Earth Sciences, the Department of Education and Human Development, and the Professional Learning Community (PLC). Earth Science is a broad field of study covering many fascinating topics including astronomy, meteorology, oceanography, and geology.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Earth Science with Students with Disabilities Certification (BS)
Requirements: To apply as a first-year student, you’ll need to submit the following: a completed SUNY Application or Common Application, an official high school transcript, and a personal essay/statement. A letter of recommendation is optional but encouraged. SUNY Brockport is test-optional; SAT/ACT scores are not required for admission.
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Earth Science major provides students with a strong background in the physical and historical aspects of Earth sciences. In addition to a core curriculum of Earth Science courses, students choose from a variety of electives allowing them to customize their academic experience. Required courses include geology, meteorology, oceanography, astronomy, and environmental science. A strong emphasis is placed on field experiences. Completion of the Earth Science Adolescence Education BS degree fulfills the New York State academic requirements to be recommended for initial certification in Earth Science (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).

Requirements: Admission to the College at Brockport does not guarantee admission to the teacher education program. To be eligible for admission to the adolescence inclusive generalist teacher certification program, students must have an overall Brockport GPA of 3.0 or higher. Students should declare their major in adolescence education and the content area as early as possible to receive appropriate advisement.
Description: The Adolescence Education: English program at SUNY Brockport prepares you to teach English (grades 7-12) in New York State public schools. This program combines a liberal arts education in English with professional coursework, field experiences, and student teaching. As a student in this program, you will develop a deep understanding of English language arts, including literature, writing, and language. You will also learn effective teaching strategies, classroom management techniques, and how to create an inclusive and equitable learning environment for all students. Our program emphasizes hands-on experience, with extensive opportunities for field placements in diverse school settings.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: English with Students with Disabilities Certification Program (BS)
Requirements: Students can apply using the SUNY Application or Common Application. We’ll need your official high school transcript(s) sent directly from your school. If you've taken any college-level coursework, we will need those official transcripts as well. A letter of recommendation and personal essay/statement are optional, but encouraged. SUNY Brockport is test-optional, which means you can choose whether or not to submit SAT or ACT scores as part of your application.
Description: This is an undergraduate dual certification program that leads to a Bachelor of Science (BS) degree in Adolescence Education: English (grades 7-12) with Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12). Upon successful completion of the program, students are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Adolescence Education: English (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12). The program prepares students to teach English to adolescent learners, including those with disabilities. Courses focus on subject matter content, pedagogy, and professional skills required to meet the learning needs of all students in inclusive classrooms. Supervised field experiences, including student teaching, are integral components of the program. Admission into the teacher education program is required.
Accredidation: The Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP) accredits the programs leading to initial and advanced certification for teachers and school professionals at SUNY Brockport.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies Major (BA / BS)
Description: The Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies Major (BA/BS) is a 46-credit program leading to an initial teaching certification in grades 7-12. The major is designed to provide students with a broad and deep understanding of history, government, economics, and geography, as well as the pedagogical skills necessary to teach these subjects effectively to adolescents. Students will engage in rigorous coursework that covers U.S. history, world history, and various social science disciplines. The curriculum emphasizes critical thinking, research, and analytical skills, preparing future educators to create dynamic and engaging learning environments. Field experiences and student teaching opportunities are integral components of the program, providing practical classroom experience.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BA / BS)
Requirements:
Admission to the University does not guarantee admission to the Adolescence Inclusive Generalist Education program. Students who meet the following requirements may apply for admission to the adolescence inclusive generalist teacher certification program:
1. Complete an application for admission to the teacher education program.
2. Have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher.
3. Have completed the following courses with a grade of C or higher: EDI 431 Teaching & Learning in the Inclusive Classroom; PRO 370 Health & Drug Education for Teacher Candidates; One general education writing course.
4. Submit documentation of 50 clock hours of experience working with children or adolescents.
5. Submit a Disposition Form.
Department: School of Arts and Sciences and School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: History and Social Studies with Students with Disabilities Certification major leads to New York state initial certification in both Adolescence Education: Social Studies (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12) generalist. This dual certification prepares students for careers as social studies teachers in middle and high schools, as well as special education teachers in grades 7-12. The program integrates content knowledge in history and social studies with pedagogical knowledge and skills in both general education and special education. Students complete a rigorous curriculum that includes coursework in history, political science, economics, geography, and sociology, as well as professional education courses focused on teaching methodologies, adolescent development, classroom management, and inclusive practices. Field experiences are embedded throughout the program, culminating in student teaching placements in both general education social studies and special education settings. Graduates are prepared to meet the diverse learning needs of all students in inclusive classrooms.
Accredidation: All of our teacher education programs at SUNY Brockport are registered by the New York State Education Department (NYSED) and nationally recognized by the Council for the Accreditation of Educator Preparation (CAEP).

Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: This program leads to a Bachelor of Science degree in Adolescence Education: Mathematics, and New York State initial certification to teach mathematics in grades 7-12. This program focuses on both the subject matter of mathematics and how to teach it effectively. Graduates will be prepared to teach a wide range of mathematics courses, from pre-algebra through calculus and statistics, in middle and high school settings. Through a blend of rigorous coursework in mathematics, education theory, and extensive field experiences, students develop the pedagogical skills and subject matter expertise necessary for a successful teaching career. The curriculum is designed to meet the academic and professional standards set forth by the New York State Education Department for teacher certification. This program also provides a strong foundation for students who may wish to pursue graduate studies in mathematics education or a related field.
Accredidation: Meets the academic and professional standards set forth by the New York State Education Department for teacher certification, and leads to New York State initial certification to teach mathematics in grades 7-12.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Mathematics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS)
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: Mathematics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS) prepares students for certification to teach mathematics at the secondary level (grades 7-12) and provides initial certification in Students with Disabilities Generalist (grades 7-12). Our program provides you with a strong foundation in both mathematics and education, ensuring you have the knowledge and skills necessary to be an effective teacher for all students. Upon completion of the program, students will be qualified to teach mathematics in traditional classroom settings and to work with students with disabilities in inclusive settings, resource rooms, and consultant teacher roles. You will be prepared for a rewarding career helping young people succeed.

Department: School of Arts and Sciences, School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: This program prepares students to teach physics in grades 7-12 in New York State public schools. Upon successful completion of the requirements, graduates are eligible for initial certification in New York State. Students are prepared to be highly competent teachers with strong content knowledge in physics and extensive experience in pedagogical techniques. The coursework for the major also prepares students for advanced graduate work in physics, science education, and related fields. In addition to courses in the natural sciences, mathematics, and education, the program requires an intensive student teaching experience. Students who have successfully completed the program are prepared to teach physics and general science courses at the middle and high school level. A minor in Mathematics is also required. Students will be advised by faculty in both the Department of Physics and the Department of Education and Human Development.
ScholarshipAmount: Up to $2,500 per year for freshmen

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Physics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS)
Description: The Adolescence Education: Physics with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS) prepares students to teach physics and earth science (grades 7-12) to all students, including those with disabilities. Students are required to complete a dual major, consisting of Physics (BS) and Adolescence Education (BS). The Physics component provides a deep understanding of the subject matter, including classical mechanics, electromagnetism, thermodynamics, quantum mechanics, and optics. The Adolescence Education component focuses on pedagogical strategies, classroom management, curriculum development, and student assessment, with a particular emphasis on inclusive practices for students with disabilities. Graduates are eligible for initial certification in New York State as a teacher of Physics and Earth Science (grades 7-12) and Students with Disabilities (grades 7-12).

Requirements:
Students intending to major in Adolescence Spanish Education should declare the major as early as possible, usually upon completion of the language prerequisite of SPN 212. To be admitted to the major, students must meet the following requirements:

1. Completion of a minimum of 36 college credits.
2. A minimum cumulative Brockport GPA of 2.5.
3. Completion of SPN 350 and SPN 351 with a minimum grade of "C."
4. Completion of ENL 112 with a minimum grade of "C."
5. A minimum content area GPA of 2.75 in all required Spanish coursework taken to date.
Department: School of Arts and Sciences and School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: Spanish, BS, prepares students to teach Spanish to students in grades 7-12. This program combines a liberal arts education, a thorough understanding of Spanish language and culture, and professional preparation in teaching methods and educational psychology. Upon successful completion of all program requirements, including passing required New York State Teacher Certification Examinations, students are recommended for New York State Initial Certification in Adolescence Education: Spanish (grades 7-12). This program leads to teacher certification in New York State. Graduates are eligible to pursue positions as Spanish teachers in middle schools and high schools across New York State.

ProgramName: Adolescence Education: Spanish with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS)
Department: School of Education, Health and Human Services
Description: The Adolescence Education: Spanish with Students with Disabilities Certification Major (BS) prepares students for certification in teaching Spanish in grades 7-12, as well as students with disabilities in general education settings in grades 7-12. This program combines two certification areas and allows candidates to meet all New York State requirements for initial and professional certification. The major provides students with content in Spanish, general pedagogical knowledge, and pedagogy specifically designed for Spanish instruction and for students with disabilities.

ProgramName: African and African-American Studies Major (BA, BS)
Description: The African and African-American Studies Major is an interdisciplinary program designed to examine the historical, cultural, economic, political, and social conditions of people of African descent. Students will analyze the dynamics of these factors and develop a comprehensive understanding of the African and African-American experience. The program aims to foster critical thinking, analytical skills, and a global perspective. Upon completion, students will be prepared for a variety of careers in fields such as education, social work, public policy, community development, and international relations, or for further graduate study.

Requirements: To declare a minor in African and African-American Studies, contact the department chair.
Description: The African and African American Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to give students a critical understanding of the experiences, cultures, and contributions of people of African descent. Students will analyze the historical, social, political, economic, and cultural forces that have shaped African and African American societies, both globally and locally. The minor will enhance students' abilities to engage in critical thinking, research, and effective communication about complex issues of race, identity, power, and social justice. This program prepares students to become globally aware, socially responsible citizens who can contribute to a more just and equitable world.

Aging is a multidisciplinary, global, and individual human experience. The Aging Studies Interdisciplinary Minor provides an opportunity to develop an understanding of the aging process through multiple perspectives, including health, psychology, sociology, politics, economics, history, and the arts. Courses are designed to introduce students to current topics in aging and to prepare them for careers in the growing field of gerontology. The minor complements many majors, including but not limited to, nursing, social work, public health, psychology, sociology, healthcare administration, and recreation. Students completing the minor will also be prepared for graduate study in gerontology and related fields. The minor may be completed online or on campus.

Requirements: Applicants must submit a completed application using either the SUNY Application or the Common Application, along with an official high school transcript. Standardized test scores (SAT/ACT), a letter of recommendation, and an essay/personal statement are optional and not required for a complete application.
Description: Anthropology is the scientific and humanistic study of humanity across time and space. As a holistic discipline, anthropology focuses on the interrelationships of human biology, language, culture, and society. The anthropology major at SUNY Brockport provides students with a broad and balanced understanding of the four subfields of anthropology (archaeology, biological anthropology, linguistic anthropology, and sociocultural anthropology) and the unique theoretical and methodological approaches each subfield brings to the study of humanity. Students will be provided with opportunities for hands-on learning in the classroom and through participation in community-based research, ethnographic field schools, archaeological excavations, study abroad, and internship experiences. The program offers students the option to pursue either a BA or BS degree depending on their career interests.

The Art History minor at SUNY Brockport offers students an opportunity to study art in its historical, social, and cultural contexts. Students explore art from antiquity to the present and gain an understanding of various movements, styles, and themes across different cultures and time periods. The minor provides a foundation in visual analysis and critical thinking, encouraging students to interpret and articulate their understanding of artworks. It complements a wide range of majors by enhancing students’ cultural literacy and global awareness, making it an excellent choice for those interested in careers in museums, galleries, education, conservation, or further graduate study in art history.

Concentration: Graphic Design, Illustration, New Media, Painting and Drawing, Photography, Printmaking, Sculpture, Ceramics, Art Education, Museum Studies
Description:
The Department of Art at SUNY Brockport offers Bachelor of Arts (BA), Bachelor of Science (BS), and Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degrees in Art. This page focuses on the BA and BS degrees.
The Bachelor of Arts (BA) in Art offers students a broad liberal arts education with a strong foundation in art. Students develop a comprehensive understanding of art history, theory, and practice, while also exploring various studio disciplines. The BA program emphasizes critical thinking, research, and communication skills, preparing students for diverse career paths or further graduate studies in fields such as art history, museum studies, arts administration, or art criticism.
The Bachelor of Science (BS) in Art is designed to prepare students for a career in art-related fields such as graphic design, illustration, museum studies, and art education. Students choose a concentration within the BS program. The BS program combines a strong foundation in art with focused study in a specific area, providing students with the technical skills and theoretical knowledge necessary for professional practice. Graduates of the BS program are well-prepared for entry-level positions in their chosen field or for further specialized training.

Requirements: Admission into the BFA program is by application and portfolio review only. Students who have completed the foundations coursework (or who are concurrently enrolled in the remaining foundations courses) and who have an overall GPA of 2.5 and a GPA of 3.0 in Art are eligible to apply. The application requires a portfolio of 12-15 images, an artist statement of 300 words, an unofficial transcript, and two letters of recommendation from faculty.
Description: The Bachelor of Fine Arts (BFA) degree is the professional undergraduate degree in the visual arts. It is designed for students seeking an intensive study of the visual arts within the context of a liberal arts education. Students develop high-level skills, critical thinking, and an understanding of contemporary art theory and practice as they pursue advanced work in a selected area of studio art. The program provides the knowledge and experience necessary to pursue a professional career in art or to continue their education in graduate school.

Requirements:
A minimum of 18 credits in studio art is required for the minor. Nine credits must be taken in residence at SUNY Brockport. A grade of C or higher is required in all courses for the minor. The student and the minor coordinator will design a coherent program to fit the student’s interests and goals.

Required Courses (9 credits)
ARS 211 Drawing I (3 credits)
ARS 221 Two-Dimensional Design (3 credits)
ARS 231 Three-Dimensional Design (3 credits)

Electives (9 credits)
Choose 9 credits from ARS courses at the 300/400 level.
Description: The Art - Studio Minor is intended for students who wish to pursue an area of studio art in depth without committing to a full major. Students choose a primary medium or approach in which to develop studio skills and concepts. The courses selected for this minor provide students with a solid foundation in the visual arts while allowing the flexibility to pursue individual interests. Students will take foundational courses and then advanced studio courses in their chosen area.

The biochemistry major is designed to provide students with a strong background in chemistry and biology, with an emphasis on the intersection of these two disciplines. Biochemists investigate the chemical processes within and relating to living organisms.
